abstract.p: An optimal control solution to the highly non-linear problem of orbit transfer mission is achieved by using a newly proposed analytical perturbation technique. The problem is classified as a two-point boundary value problem in order to optimize a performance measure in a given time. Assuming a constant thrust operating in a given length of time, it is sought to find the thrust direction history of a transfer from a given initial orbit to the largest possible orbit. The system dynamical model is stated by regarding a variable mass spacecraft moving in the variable gravitational field of the Earth, based on the two-body problem. To assess the perturbation solution fidelity, a numerical solution based on the Gauss pseudospectral method has been employed. The main novelty of this work is in applying a new analytical solution strategy that is a combination of perturbation technique and backward integration to a highly non-linear problem in the calculus of variations approach.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Finding an exact solution to the non-linear optimal control problem of space vehicle guidance has been of significant interest recently. In this regard, the evolution of flight vehicle dynamics poses a challenge for contemporary space missions employing classical guidance laws. On the contrary, several problems such as slow convergence rate, high sensitivity to initial guesstimates and considerable computational costs can be seen in the numerical solutions of the optimal control problems. To overcome the aforementioned innate difficulties, the analytical solutions, even with simplifying approximations, are highly recommended. In this research, development of an analytic optimal solution strategy given in reference [1] to the non-linear problem of orbital transferring to the maximum height orbit has been taken into consideration. A time-optimal guidance law for the lunar landing mission in the polar coordinate system was designed by employing the linear programming as a numeric approach [2]. On the other hand, an analytic optimal solution for the non-linear problem of satellite injection in the Cartesian coordination was obtained using a variational approach [3]. Furthermore, an optimal guidance law to maximum radius orbit transfer problem in the polar coordinate system has been determined by Koop and McGill numerically, see reference [4]. A more comprehensive approach of the perturbation technique that has been employed in this study for solving non-linear differential equations is introduced by Nayfeh [5, 6].

A novel real-time guidance scheme for advanced launch systems was obtained by constructing an optimal guidance law based on the asymptotic expansion of regular perturbation technique [7]. Leung and Calise have also introduced a hybrid technique to the launch vehicle ascent guidance to a predetermined orbit. They used a feedback approach based on a nearly piecewise analytical solution by using the collocation method [8]. A novel approach to synthesize the optimal feedback law for the satellite injection problem is introduced using fuzzy systems by Pourtakdoust et al. [9] In this work, an attempt was made to develop the closed-loop fuzzy guidance law in the presence of environment noises and system uncertainties. Afshari et al. [1, 10–12] and Roshanian et al. [13] have tried to design optimal guidance solutions for different space missions by employing mathematical theories, such as perturbation theorem, backward sweep method, and calculus of variations in exact forms. Considering novel approaches of control theories such as fuzzy guidance law (FGL) and L1 adaptive method has caused new guidance solutions to be achieved. The backward sweep method is an approach in solving optimal control problems with terminal constraints, when it is sought to transform the differential equations to a form that can be solved by backward integration from terminal conditions to initial conditions, either analytically or numerically.

The problem of orbit transfer guidance has been taken into consideration by researchers for several years. Williams [14] investigated a modern numerical solution for the low thrust orbit transfer problem by developing the Jacobi pseudospectral method. The Gauss’s variational equations (GVEs) are used to model the state–space dynamics of motion. Afterwards, based on the accessibility results, a non-linear feedback controller was derived which can asymptotically steer a spacecraft from an initial elliptic orbit to any given elliptic orbit [15]. One of the most difficult problems in the aero-capture is the presence of strong air density variations in the upper atmosphere. To this end, Rozanov and Guelman [16] presented a basic approach on tracking a reference trajectory in state–space. An optimal guidance law that minimized the commanded acceleration in three dimensions was obtained by Dsouza [17]. This law is an exact solution to the two-point boundary value problem associated with the first variation necessary conditions. An optimal transfer method of a satellite between Keplerian orbits, while using low propulsion based on the approximation of averaging techniques, was also investigated [18]. Guelman et al. [19] designed a new analytic algorithm to solve the two-point boundary value problem by employing Pontryagin principle and the transfer trajectory was presented as an illustration of the proposed technique.

The present study concentrates on the development of a methodology to determine an optimal guidance solution for the non-linear problem of orbit transfer mission in the Earth’s gravitational system. The main novelty of this study is to propose a non-linear optimization solution to the orbit transfer problem, while it is possible to apply it to other optimization problems in the aerospace systems. To avoid several common difficulties which have appeared in the numerical solutions of previous researches [3, 7, 8, 14], such as slow convergence rate, and high sensitivity to initial guesstimates, an analytic solution strategy is taken into consideration. Generally speaking, obtaining an analytic solution to the highly non-linear time-varying problem of orbit transfer problem is the main goal of this study. Furthermore, to examine the accuracy of the proposed analytic solution, a numerical approach of Gauss pseudospectral method (GPM) has been used for comparison.

The problem is formulated as a thrust directional control program to transfer a point-mass spacecraft from an initial orbit to the largest possible orbit in a given time. By utilizing the two-body theorem formulation and following Newton’s second law of gravity, the gravitational system of Earth and spacecraft is derived as a function of spacecraft altitude simultaneously. To solve the state–space equations analytically, two perturbation parameters associated with variations in the spacecraft mass and gravitational coefficient are regarded. Afterwards, the non-linear optimal control and state trajectories using the perturbation technique are obtained. sec.title: 5 NUMERICAL SOLUTION USING THE GAUSS PSEUDOSPECTRAL METHOD (GPM)
sec.p: Pseudospectral (PS) methods arose from spectral methods which were traditionally used to solve fluid dynamics problems. In optimal control they are known as ‘orthogonal collocation methods’ and are amongst the powerful computational techniques and have gained popularity during the past several years with various PS algorithms developed since the 1990s. In general, numerical solution of an optimal control problem requires the approximation of three types of mathematical objects, i.e. the integration in the cost function, the differential equation of the control system, and the state-control constraints. An ideal approximation method should be efficient for all these aforementioned key tasks.

A method that is efficient in one of them, for instance an efficient ODE solver, may not be an efficient method for the other two objects. These requirements make PS methods ideal because they are efficient for the approximation of all three mathematical objects as proved in references [20, 21]. These methods include forms of the collocation at Legendre–Gauss–Lobatto points [21, 22], collocation at Chebyshev–Gauss–Lobatto points [23], and Legendre–Gauss points ([24–27]; known as the Gauss PS Method). Basically, they are very similar to the method of collocation. The main differences are with the way they construct the representative polynomials and the defects (Δ) computation [28]. When the PS method is employed, a polynomial representation of the states is constructed and a number of constraints are enforced so that the slopes of the polynomials agree with the differential equations at a finite number of points. Typically, these nodes are Gauss points, Gauss–Radau points, or Gauss–Lobatto points. The quadrature nodes are determined by the corresponding orthogonal polynomial basis used for the approximation. State values are then established at some nodes. Using the state values, Lagrange interpolation is used to construct a new polynomial based on the state interpolation. These representative polynomials differentiated and evaluated at all nodes are used to compute interpolated time derivative values of the states. The equations of motion are evaluated to provide the values of the physical time derivatives. Finally, the difference between these two sets of time derivatives forms the defects. At all nodes the slope of the polynomial is required to be equal to f(x) = dx/dt. The procedure is shown in Fig. 4.

The final defect relation converts toΔ={p '}-f=[D]{x}-f=0. Using this formulation for the pseudospectral method, the values of [D] are dependent only on the chosen node spacing. This allows for other PS variants to be generated by simply changing the nodal distribution.

The GPM method differs from several other PS methods in that the dynamics are not collocated at either endpoint of the time interval. In GPM specifically the points at which the optimal control problem is discretized, are the Legendre–Gauss points. The approach used in the GPM is to use a Lagrange polynomial approximation for the state that includes coefficients for the initial state plus the values of the state at the N Legendre–Gauss points. In a somewhat opposite manner, the approximation for the co-state is performed using a basis of Lagrange polynomials that includes the final value of the co-state, plus the co-state at the N points. The co-state mapping theorem that arises from the GPM has been described in several references including two MIT PhD and one Master’s theses [25, 26, 29] and journal articles that include the theory along with applications. For more information on GPM the reader should consult the mentioned references. A similar version of the Earth-to-Mars Orbit raising problem is addressed in [28] and solved with three different direct methods, i.e. collocation, GPM, and multiple shooting, and a good comparison for algorithm performance is presented there in terms of accuracy and CPU time. Altogether, the collocation and GPS methods have the same performance for the orbit raising problem. To examine the accuracy of analytical results, a powerful numerical approach of Gauss PS method is also utilized in this work. Optimal control and state trajectories obtained from the numerical approach of GPM for transferring to the maximum possible orbit are depicted in Figs 5–9 by dashed lines.

sec.title: 6 SIMULATION RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p: After contrasting the analytical results with numerical ones, good agreements between the two different approaches are obtained and the accuracy of the proposed analytic solution is proved. The main advantage of the proposed analytic solution with respect to other previous analytic works of references [3], [9], and [17] is that the derived dynamic model contains more complexities, such as variable mass spacecraft and variable gravitational acceleration, which will be more practical for real world applications. When, in references [3], [9], and [17], these terms are constant, it makes a considerable error in the results. Even though the models proposed in references [7] and [8] have enough accuracy for modeling, the introduced solution utilizes a numeric approach in addition to the analytic one and the difficulties associated with numerical solutions may appear. Other studies, such as references [14] and [22], have focused on the numerical optimization methods that may have several disadvantages, such as slow convergence rate, high sensitivity to initial guesstimates, and considerable computational errors.

Having considered the profiles of Figs 5–9, it can be concluded that all the boundary conditions of equations (21) and (22) are satisfied, thus the orbit transfer mission was performed appropriately. The vertical velocity components of the spacecraft in launching and injecting instances are zero and it means that in these two stages, the spacecraft moves in a tangential direction with respect to related orbits. The height of the maximum possible orbit is 1.243, when the height of the initial orbit is 1. The maximum value of control effort expenditure is related to the time of changing the vertical velocity direction between 0.75 and 0.85, when the maximum variations in the thrust angle are applied. Also, by observing the thrust angle profile, the effect of the derived linear tangent law is easily demonstrated.

In the following, it is attempted to inspect the effects of variations of gravitational acceleration and spacecraft mass on the optimal solution. In this way, four scenarios for the orbit transfer mission can be designed as presented in Table 2. Properties of these scenarios and the maximum orbit height are given in Table 2. The first scenario is that the spacecraft mass and Earth’s gravitational coefficient are assumed to be constant, while in the second and third scenarios only the gravitational acceleration and mass rate are varying, respectively. In the fourth scenario, both parameters are varying simultaneously. Having inspected the tabulated values, it can be concluded that in the fourth scenario, the spacecraft will transfer to the orbit with minimum possible height. In addition, the first scenario has the largest possible orbit height among these scenarios. Consequently, it can be demonstrated that the magnitude of maximum orbit height is decreased by adding the gravitational effect on the simple problem. sec.title: 7 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this study, a new optimal guidance solution for the non-linear orbit transfer problem employing perturbation technique is obtained. It is derived analytically by combining the theory of perturbation series and backward sweep integration method. The problem concludes two highly non-linear terms related to real applications of spacecraft missions. Comparison between achieved analytic results and numerical results demonstrate the good accuracy of the applied perturbation approach to investigate the effect of variations in the mass and gravitational field on the solution.

Furthermore, having regarded the tabulated results, it is concluded that by affecting the spacecraft mass and Earth’s gravitational coefficient the maximum possible height will decrease. Thus, with neglecting these two perturbation parameters, the largest orbit height is resulted. Due to the analytic nature of solution process, some usual difficulties associated with the numerical solution of the optimal control problem for non-linear systems, such as slow convergence rate and high sensitivity to initial guesstimates do not appear. In other words, presenting a desirable analytical solution is the main advantage of this study with contrast to the other numerical methodologies discussed in the introduction section.
